Award.AwardTitle: NSF Postdoctoral Fellowship in Biology FY 2010
Award.AbstractNarration:
This action funds an NSF Minority Postdoctoral Research Fellowship for FY 2010. The fellowship supports a research and training plan in a host laboratory for the Fellow who also presents a plan to broaden participation in biology. The title of the research and training plan for this fellowship to Rebecca Cole is "Understanding carbon storage in extremely wet tropical forests." The host institution for this research is the University of Colorado at Boulder and the sponsoring scientist is Dr. Alan Townsend.

Tropical forests play a critical role in the terrestrial carbon budget. Global efforts to reduce carbon emissions from tropical deforestation and degradation are increasing along with implementation of novel market instruments, such as Payments for Environmental Services (PES), to enhance carbon sequestration. Yet information on the carbon dynamics of intact tropical forests and the degraded forest types that are rapidly replacing them is lacking, particularly in the wettest portions of the tropical biome where rates of biosphere-atmosphere carbon exchange are exceptionally high. This research is generating baseline data on the carbon stocks and fluxes in extremely wet topical forest and forest types currently under PES initiatives: intact rainforest, selectively logged and successional forests, and forestry plantations.

The training objectives include developing expertise in field and laboratory-based techniques in biogeochemistry, broadening the Fellow's knowledge of rainforest biogeochemistry and ecosystem responses to climate change, and improving grant writing, mentorship, and outreach skills. The results of this project enable an evaluation of carbon storage that will inform carbon offset programs in Costa Rica and other tropical countries. The research will produce key ground-truthing measures for high spatial resolution airborne imaging spectroscopy of forests allowing for mapping of carbon storage over a broad geographic region. The project also provides research experience for Costa Rica and US undergraduate students and outreach to local communities and schools. The results of this project are being disseminated through publication in major research journals, presentation at national meetings, and to Costa Rican conservation, government, and university groups.

POR.DRECONTENT:
Tropical forests play a key role in global biogeochemical cycles and provide a range of critical ecosystem services. But throughout the tropics, forests have been extensively cleared and degraded leading to elevated CO2 emissions and altered ecosystem functions. Over large areas of Central America, primary forests have been replaced with succession forests of different ages. Understanding how key ecosystem functions, and the mechanism underlying these functions, have been altered and how they recover with time during succession is important for managing these resources and informing efforts to restore and conserve biodiversity. Our understanding of factors that constrain ecosystem function and recovery is lacking in comparison to the immense variability and global importance of this biome. Our understanding is particularly poor in the wettest portion of the tropics (>3500 mm annual precipitation) which represents some of the most diverse areas on earth and have some of the highest rates of biosphere-atmosphere carbon exchange. This research explored several aspects of tropical forest recovery in lowland and montane tropical forests in southern Costa Rica. These included establishing and measuring tree species in a set of twenty 0.5 long-term forest monitoring plots of different ages, measuring aspects of carbon uptake and cycling, evaluating how insect and other arthropod communities recover in experimentaly restored forests, and testing how soil micro-biota (bacteria and fungi) may aid or reduce the recovery of native tree species on degraded lands.

There are several major outcomes to this project. First, the data collected provides useful information for quantifying carbon storage and cycling in wet, lowland tropical forest. Second, a major finding of this project is that the activities of arthropods that live in leaf litter and soil have a large effect on the rates of carbon and nitrogen cycling in these ecosystems. However, these arthropod communities appear to be very slow to recover during natural forest regeneration and under different strategies to restore forest through tree planting. A third major finding is that soil biota appear to play a very significant role in tree community composition during forest succession. Taken together, these results can inform efforts to manage and restore tropical forests and help us to quantify carbon storage and fluxes in intact and regenerating forests. This research also provided training opportunities for several Costa Rican technician and Costa Rican and US undergraduate students. The results of this project have been made available to Costa Rican conservation organizations and National Park administration in the study region.
